Apple_Apple_scab.name: Apple Scab
Apple_Apple_scab.description: A fungal disease that causes olive-green or brown spots on leaves and fruit.
treatment: Remove and destroy fallen leaves in autumn
Apply fungicides at green tip stage

chemical.name: Mancozeb + Myclobutanil
chemical.precautions: Wear protective clothing during application. Keep away from water bodies.

video_sources.primary: Search: 'Apple Scab Disease Management University Extension'
reliable_channels: University of California Agriculture and Natural Resources

organic.name: Sulfur spray
organic.precautions: Apply in cool weather to avoid leaf burn. Do not apply when temperatures exceed 80°F.

video_sources.primary: Search: 'Organic Apple Scab Treatment Sulfur Spray'

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor weather conditions - apply preventative treatments before rain
2. Start applications at green tip stage (early spring)
3. Ensure complete coverage of leaves and developing fruit
4. Repeat applications based on weather and product label
5. Maintain spray schedule through petal fall and early fruit development

Apple_Black_rot.name: Apple Black Rot
Apple_Black_rot.description: A fungal disease causing leaf spots, fruit rot, and cankers on branches.

chemical.name: Captan + Thiophanate-methyl
chemical.precautions: Apply during dry weather. Avoid application before rain.

video_sources.primary: Search: 'Apple Black Rot Disease Management Extension'

organic.name: Copper hydroxide
organic.precautions: May cause fruit russeting in some apple varieties.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Inspect trees during dormant season for cankers and mummified fruit
2. Remove and destroy all infected material
3. Begin fungicide applications at pink bud stage
4. Continue through petal fall and early fruit development
5. Focus on thorough coverage of fruit clusters
6. Maintain proper orchard sanitation throughout season

Apple_Cedar_apple_rust.name: Apple Cedar Apple Rust
Apple_Cedar_apple_rust.description: A fungal disease causing bright yellow-orange spots on apple leaves and orange gelatinous growths on cedar trees.
treatment: Remove nearby cedar trees if possible

chemical.name: Myclobutanil
chemical.precautions: Begin applications at green tip. Continue until dry weather.

organic.name: Lime sulfur
organic.precautions: Apply during dormant season. May cause leaf burn if applied during growing season.

video_sources.primary: Search: 'Organic Apple Rust Control Lime Sulfur'
reliable_channels: ATTRA National Center for Appropriate Technology

step_by_step_guide: 1. Identify nearby cedar/juniper trees (alternate host)
2. Begin monitoring apple trees at bud break
3. Apply first fungicide at green tip stage
4. Continue applications through bloom period
5. Focus treatments during wet spring weather
6. Consider removing alternate hosts within 2 miles if possible

Apple_healthy.name: Healthy Apple
Apple_healthy.description: Your apple trees appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Preventative fungicide spray
chemical.precautions: Apply during dormant season and early spring.

organic.name: Neem oil + Sulfur
organic.precautions: Apply in early morning or evening to prevent leaf burn.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Implement dormant season cleanup and pruning
2. Monitor weather conditions for disease-favorable periods
3. Apply preventative treatments at key growth stages
4. Maintain proper tree spacing for air circulation
5. Regular inspection for early disease detection
6. Keep detailed spray records for future reference

Blueberry_healthy.name: Healthy Blueberry
Blueberry_healthy.description: Your blueberry plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Azoxystrobin
chemical.precautions: Apply before bloom and after harvest. Rotate with other fungicides.

organic.name: Bacillus subtilis
organic.precautions: Apply in early morning when humidity is high.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Test and maintain acidic soil pH between 4.5-5.5
2. Ensure proper drainage and mulching
3. Prune during dormant season for air circulation
4. Monitor for common diseases like mummy berry and anthracnose
5. Apply preventative treatments before bloom
6. Maintain consistent irrigation without wetting foliage

Cherry_Powdery_mildew.name: Cherry Powdery Mildew
Cherry_Powdery_mildew.description: A fungal disease causing white powdery spots on leaves and stems, which can lead to leaf distortion and premature leaf drop.
treatment: Apply fungicides at first sign of infection
Remove and destroy infected plant parts

chemical.name: Myclobutanil
chemical.precautions: Do not apply within 7 days of harvest. Apply at first sign of disease.

organic.name: Potassium bicarbonate
organic.precautions: Apply during low humidity conditions. May require multiple applications.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor trees weekly during warm, dry weather
2. Look for white powdery growth on young shoots and leaves
3. Apply first treatment at early symptom appearance
4. Ensure thorough coverage of upper and lower leaf surfaces
5. Continue treatments every 7-14 days as needed
6. Prune infected shoots during dormant season

Cherry_healthy.name: Healthy Cherry
Cherry_healthy.description: Your cherry trees appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Copper-based fungicide
chemical.precautions: Apply during dormant season. May cause fruit russeting if applied near harvest.

organic.name: Neem oil
organic.precautions: Apply in early morning or evening to prevent leaf burn.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Implement dormant season pruning and cleanup
2. Apply dormant oil during late winter
3. Monitor for brown rot during bloom
4. Maintain proper tree spacing and pruning
5. Apply preventative treatments as needed
6. Harvest fruit promptly to reduce disease pressure

Corn_Cercospora_leaf_spot.name: Corn Cercospora Leaf Spot (Gray Leaf Spot)
Corn_Cercospora_leaf_spot.description: A fungal disease that appears as rectangular lesions that follow leaf veins, typically tan to gray in color.

chemical.name: Azoxystrobin + Propiconazole
chemical.precautions: Best applied before disease development. Rotate with different mode of action fungicides to prevent resistance.

video_sources.primary: Search: 'Corn Gray Leaf Spot Disease Management'

organic.name: Copper hydroxide
organic.precautions: Apply early in disease development. May require multiple applications in wet conditions.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout fields regularly starting at tasseling stage
2. Look for rectangular lesions parallel to leaf veins
3. Apply fungicide when disease first appears on lower leaves
4. Focus treatments during periods of high humidity
5. Use crop rotation with non-host crops
6. Select resistant hybrids for future plantings

Corn(maize)_Common_rust.name: Corn Common Rust
Corn(maize)_Common_rust.description: A fungal disease characterized by small, circular to elongate pustules that are brick-red to brown in color.
treatment: Apply fungicides at first signs of infection
Monitor fields regularly during humid conditions

chemical.name: Tebuconazole
chemical.precautions: Do not apply within 21 days of harvest. Apply at first sign of disease.

organic.name: Sulfur dust
organic.precautions: Do not apply when temperatures exceed 85°F. Apply in early morning.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Begin scouting at whorl stage through grain fill
2. Look for rust pustules on upper and lower leaf surfaces
3. Apply fungicide when 50% of plants show symptoms
4. Time applications during cool, humid weather
5. Monitor for southern rust which is more aggressive
6. Consider hybrid resistance ratings for future seasons

Corn_Northern_Leaf_Blight.name: Corn Northern Leaf Blight
Corn_Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: A fungal disease causing long, elliptical, grayish-green to tan lesions on corn leaves.

chemical.name: Pyraclostrobin + Metconazole
chemical.precautions: Apply before disease development. Do not apply within 30 days of harvest.

organic.name: Bacillus subtilis
organic.precautions: Most effective when applied preventatively. Multiple applications required.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout fields from V6 growth stage onward
2. Look for elliptical lesions starting on lower leaves
3. Apply fungicide when disease reaches lower ear leaf
4. Time applications before tasseling for best results
5. Use crop rotation with non-host crops like soybeans
6. Select hybrids with resistance ratings for your area

Corn_healthy.name: Healthy Corn
Corn_healthy.description: Your corn plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Preventative fungicide mix
chemical.precautions: Rotate between different classes of fungicides to prevent resistance.

organic.name: Compost tea
organic.usage: Dilute and spray as soil drench/foliar
organic.precautions: Apply in early morning or evening. Use within 24 hours of brewing.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Implement balanced fertility program
2. Practice crop rotation with legumes
3. Monitor for diseases throughout growing season
4. Maintain adequate plant populations
5. Control weeds to reduce disease pressure
6. Select appropriate hybrids for local conditions

Grape_Esca_Black_Measles.name: Grape Esca (Black Measles)
Grape_Esca_Black_Measles.description: A complex fungal disease causing leaf spots, wood decay, and berry symptoms including dark spots and shriveling.
treatment: Remove and destroy infected wood during pruning
Improve vineyard drainage and air circulation

chemical.name: Sodium arsenite (restricted use)
chemical.precautions: Highly restricted pesticide. Professional application required. Extreme toxicity.

video_sources.primary: Search: 'Grape Esca Disease Management Professional Treatment'

organic.name: Trichoderma harzianum
organic.precautions: Apply immediately after making cuts. Store in cool, dry conditions.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Inspect vines during dormant season for cankers and dead wood
2. Prune out infected wood 6 inches below visible damage
3. Apply wound protectant immediately after cuts
4. Disinfect pruning tools between vines
5. Remove and destroy all infected wood
6. Monitor for foliar symptoms during growing season

Grape_Leaf_blight_Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot.name: Grape Leaf Blight (Isariopsis Leaf Spot)
Grape_Leaf_blight_Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot.description: A fungal disease causing dark brown to black angular spots on leaves, often with yellow halos.
treatment: Improve air circulation through canopy management
Apply protective fungicides during wet periods

chemical.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole
chemical.precautions: Begin applications at first sign of disease. Do not apply within 21 days of harvest.

organic.name: Potassium bicarbonate + Horticultural oil
organic.precautions: Apply in early morning or evening. Test on small area first.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout vineyard weekly during humid conditions
2. Look for angular dark spots on older leaves first
3. Remove affected leaves and improve air circulation
4. Apply fungicide at first sign of symptoms
5. Continue treatments through harvest
6. Clean up leaf debris in fall

Grape_healthy.name: Healthy Grape
Grape_healthy.description: Your grape vines appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Copper sulfate + Lime
chemical.precautions: Apply during dormant season and early growth. Avoid application near harvest.

organic.name: Sulfur + Mineral oil
organic.precautions: Do not apply when temperatures exceed 85°F. Apply in early morning.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Implement proper pruning and canopy management
2. Maintain good vineyard sanitation
3. Monitor weather conditions for disease pressure
4. Apply preventative treatments at key growth stages
5. Regular scouting for early disease detection
6. Harvest at proper maturity to reduce disease risk

Orange_Haunglongbing_Citrus_greening.name: Orange Huanglongbing (Citrus Greening)
Orange_Haunglongbing_Citrus_greening.description: A bacterial disease transmitted by Asian citrus psyllid, causing yellow shoots, asymmetrical mottling, and bitter, misshapen fruit.

chemical.name: Imidacloprid + Foliar nutritionals
chemical.precautions: Focus on psyllid control. Tree removal is often necessary.

organic.name: Kaolin clay + Neem oil
organic.precautions: Focus on vector control. Organic methods have limited effectiveness.

step_by_Step_guide: 1. Regular inspection for psyllid adults and nymphs
2. Monitor for early symptoms: yellow shoots, leaf mottling
4. Apply foliar nutritionals to support tree health
6. Replant only with certified disease-free stock

Peach_Bacterial_spot.name: Peach Bacterial Spot
Peach_Bacterial_spot.description: A bacterial disease causing small dark spots on leaves, water-soaked lesions on fruit, and twig cankers.

chemical.name: Copper sulfate + Oxytetracycline
chemical.precautions: Begin applications at petal fall. Do not apply copper within 30 days of harvest.

organic.name: Copper hydroxide + Bacillus subtilis
organic.precautions: Reduce copper use by alternating with biological products. Apply during dry weather.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Begin scouting after petal fall for leaf spots
2. Look for small, dark angular spots with yellow halos
3. Apply first treatment at petal fall
4. Continue weekly applications during wet weather
5. Focus on young, susceptible tissue
6. Prune infected twigs during dormant season

Peach_healthy.name: Healthy Peach
Peach_healthy.description: Your peach trees appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease
Follow proper pruning and sanitation practices

chemical.name: Copper-based fungicide
chemical.precautions: Apply during dormant season to prevent bacterial and fungal diseases.

organic.name: Horticultural oil + Compost tea
organic.usage: Dormant oil application + growing season tea
organic.precautions: Apply oil during dormant season only. Brew compost tea fresh.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Apply dormant season treatments for disease prevention
2. Prune for good air circulation and light penetration
3. Monitor for brown rot during bloom and near harvest
4. Thin fruit to reduce disease pressure
5. Maintain proper tree nutrition
6. Remove mummified fruit and fallen leaves

Pepper_bell_Bacterial_spot.name: Pepper Bell Bacterial Spot
Pepper_bell_Bacterial_spot.description: A bacterial disease causing small, dark spots on leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation and unmarketable peppers.
treatment: Avoid overhead irrigation and work in wet fields

chemical.name: Copper sulfate + Mancozeb
chemical.precautions: Begin applications at transplanting. Rotate with other bactericides to prevent resistance.

organic.name: Copper octanoate + Plant essential oils
organic.precautions: Apply during cooler parts of day. May require more frequent applications.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Start with certified disease-free transplants
2. Begin preventative treatments at transplanting
3. Scout weekly for small, dark leaf spots
4. Apply treatments before and after rain events
5. Remove severely infected plants
6. Rotate to non-host crops for 2-3 years

Pepper_bell_healthy.name: Pepper Bell Healthy
Pepper_bell_healthy.description: Your bell pepper plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Preventative copper spray
chemical.precautions: Apply preventatively during humid conditions. Avoid during fruit development.

organic.name: Bacillus amyloliquefaciens
organic.precautions: Apply during cooler parts of day. Store in refrigerator.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Provide consistent moisture without waterlogging
2. Mulch around plants to reduce soil splash
3. Space plants adequately for air circulation
4. Monitor for pests and diseases weekly
5. Apply preventative treatments during humid weather
6. Harvest regularly to maintain plant health

Potato_Early_blight.name: Potato Early Blight
Potato_Early_blight.description: A fungal disease causing dark, concentric ring spots on leaves and tubers, leading to premature defoliation.
treatment: Apply fungicides at first sign of disease
Remove and destroy infected plant debris

chemical.name: Chlorothalonil + Azoxystrobin
chemical.precautions: Begin applications when disease first appears. Do not apply within 7 days of harvest.

organic.name: Copper hydroxide + Bacillus subtilis
organic.precautions: Apply copper during dry weather. Use biological product during humid conditions.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout fields weekly starting mid-season
2. Look for dark spots with concentric rings on lower leaves
3. Apply fungicide at first symptom appearance
4. Continue applications based on weather conditions
5. Focus on protecting new growth and tubers
6. Practice 3-4 year crop rotation

Potato_Late_blight.name: Potato Late Blight
Potato_Late_blight.description: A devastating fungal-like disease causing water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and tubers, capable of destroying entire crops quickly.

chemical.name: Metalaxyl + Mancozeb
chemical.precautions: Apply preventatively. Most effective when applied before infection occurs.

organic.name: Copper sulfate + Potassium phosphonate
organic.precautions: Requires intensive application schedule. Limited effectiveness compared to conventional.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor weather conditions for late blight favorable periods
2. Begin preventative applications before disease arrival
3. Scout fields daily during high-risk periods
4. Remove infected plants immediately and completely
5. Apply fungicides on intensive schedule
6. Destroy crop residue and volunteer potatoes

Potato_healthy.name: Healthy Potato
Potato_healthy.description: Your potato plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Preventative fungicide rotation
chemical.precautions: Rotate between different fungicide classes. Begin mid-season applications.

organic.name: Compost tea + Beneficial microorganisms
organic.precautions: Use fresh compost tea within 24 hours. Apply during cooler parts of day.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes
2. Maintain consistent soil moisture
3. Hill soil around stems as plants grow
4. Monitor for Colorado potato beetle and diseases
5. Apply preventative treatments during high-risk periods
6. Harvest at proper maturity and cure properly

Raspberry_healthy.name: Healthy Raspberry
Raspberry_healthy.description: Your raspberry plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease
Maintain proper spacing for air circulation

chemical.name: Lime sulfur
chemical.precautions: Apply only during dormant season. Do not apply to actively growing plants.

organic.name: Horticultural oil + Sulfur
organic.precautions: Apply oil during dormant season only. Use sulfur during growing season.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Prune out old canes after harvest
2. Thin new canes for proper spacing
3. Apply dormant season treatments
4. Monitor for anthracnose and cane blight
5. Maintain good air circulation between rows
6. Remove any weak or diseased canes promptly

Soybean_healthy.name: Healthy Soybean
Soybean_healthy.description: Your soybean plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Azoxystrobin + Propiconazole
chemical.precautions: Apply during reproductive stages for maximum benefit. Monitor for resistance.

organic.name: Bacillus subtilis + Foliar nutrients
organic.precautions: Apply during cooler parts of day. Combine with micronutrients.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Plant high-quality, treated seed
2. Maintain proper plant populations
3. Scout fields regularly for diseases and pests
4. Apply preventative treatments during reproductive stages
5. Monitor for sudden death syndrome and white mold
6. Harvest at proper moisture content

Squash_Powdery_mildew.name: Squash Powdery Mildew
Squash_Powdery_mildew.description: A fungal disease causing white, powdery growth on leaves and stems, leading to yellowing and premature leaf drop.
treatment: Apply fungicides at first sign of infection

chemical.name: Myclobutanil + Sulfur
chemical.precautions: Begin applications at first sign of disease. Do not apply sulfur when temperatures exceed 85°F.

organic.name: Potassium bicarbonate + Horticultural oil
organic.precautions: Apply during cooler parts of day. Test on small area first.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor plants weekly for white powdery spots
2. Improve air circulation by proper spacing
3. Apply treatment at first sign of infection
4. Focus on upper and lower leaf surfaces
5. Remove severely infected leaves
6. Continue treatments through harvest

Strawberry_Leaf_scorch.name: Strawberry Leaf Scorch
Strawberry_Leaf_scorch.description: A fungal disease causing purple to brown spots on leaves that eventually turn brown and scorched in appearance.

chemical.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole
chemical.precautions: Begin applications during renovation after harvest. Do not apply during bloom.

organic.name: Copper octanoate + Bacillus amyloliquefaciens
organic.precautions: Apply copper during dry weather. Use biological during humid conditions.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout plants weekly during growing season
2. Look for purple spots that turn brown and scorched
3. Remove infected leaves during renovation
4. Apply fungicides after renovation mowing
5. Maintain proper plant spacing
6. Clean up debris in fall

Strawberry_healthy.name: Healthy Strawberry
Strawberry_healthy.description: Your strawberry plants appear healthy with no signs of disease or pest infestation.
treatment: Monitor for early signs of disease

chemical.name: Captan
chemical.precautions: Begin applications at bloom. Do not apply within 1 day of harvest.

organic.name: Neem oil + Beneficial microorganisms
organic.precautions: Apply neem during cooler parts of day. Apply microorganisms to soil.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Maintain proper plant spacing for air circulation
2. Apply preventative treatments during bloom
3. Remove runners to maintain plant vigor
4. Monitor for gray mold and leaf spot diseases
5. Renovate beds after harvest
6. Apply winter protection as needed

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.name: Tomato Two-Spotted Spider Mite
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.description: Tiny arachnid pests that cause stippling, yellowing, and webbing on leaves, leading to reduced plant vigor and yield.

chemical.name: Abamectin + Spiromesifen
chemical.precautions: Rotate miticide modes of action. Apply when mites first detected.

organic.name: Predatory mites + Neem oil + Insecticidal soap
organic.precautions: Do not spray neem when predatory mites are present. Increase humidity.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor plants weekly for stippling and webbing
2. Check undersides of leaves for tiny moving dots
3. Increase humidity around plants if possible
4. Release predatory mites for biological control
5. Apply miticides before heavy infestations develop
6. Remove heavily infested leaves and debris

Tomato_Bacterial_spot.name: Bacterial Spot
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.description: A bacterial disease caused by Xanthomonas species that creates small, dark brown to black spots on leaves, stems, and fruit. Spots on leaves may have yellow halos and can cause defoliation.
treatment: Improve air circulation and avoid overhead watering

chemical.name: Copper hydroxide + Streptomycin sulfate
chemical.usage: Foliar spray covering all plant surfaces
chemical.precautions: Do not apply during bloom period. Rotate with other bactericides to prevent resistance.

organic.name: Copper octanoate + Bacillus subtilis
organic.precautions: Apply copper during dry conditions. Use biological treatments during humid weather.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Inspect plants weekly for small dark spots on leaves
2. Remove infected leaves and destroy debris
3. Begin preventive sprays before disease appears
4. Apply bactericides during dry weather
5. Maintain proper plant spacing for air circulation
6. Sanitize tools between plants

Tomato_Early_blight.name: Early Blight
Tomato_Early_blight.description: A fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani that creates concentric ring spots on older leaves, progressing upward. Causes yellowing, defoliation, and fruit rot with dark, sunken lesions.
treatment: Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash
Ensure proper spacing and air circulation

chemical.name: Chlorothalonil + Azoxystrobin
chemical.precautions: Begin applications when first symptoms appear. Alternate active ingredients to prevent resistance.

organic.name: Copper sulfate + Trichoderma harzianum
organic.precautions: Apply copper in dry conditions. Use biological agents during favorable weather.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor lower leaves for brown spots with concentric rings
2. Remove affected leaves below first fruit cluster
3. Apply mulch to prevent soil splash onto leaves
4. Begin fungicide applications at first sign of disease
5. Maintain consistent watering schedule
6. Remove plant debris at end of season

Tomato_Late_blight.name: Late Blight
Tomato_Late_blight.description: A devastating disease caused by Phytophthora infestans that creates water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, with white fuzzy growth on leaf undersides. Can destroy entire crops rapidly.
treatment: Apply fungicides preventively in high-risk conditions
Ensure excellent drainage and air circulation
Monitor weather conditions for disease-favorable periods

chemical.name: Metalaxyl-M + Chlorothalonil
chemical.precautions: Begin applications before disease symptoms appear. Critical during cool, wet weather.

organic.name: Copper hydroxide + Potassium bicarbonate
organic.precautions: Organic control is limited. Focus on prevention and environmental management.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor weather forecasts for late blight-favorable conditions
2. Begin preventive fungicide program before symptoms appear
3. Scout plants daily during high-risk periods
4. Remove infected plants immediately and destroy
5. Avoid overhead irrigation during humid periods
6. Report outbreaks to local extension office

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.name: Leaf Mold
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.description: A fungal disease caused by Passalora fulva (formerly Fulvia fulva) that creates yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces with olive-green to brown fuzzy growth on undersides. Thrives in humid greenhouse conditions.

chemical.name: Propiconazole + Cyprodinil
chemical.precautions: Most effective in greenhouse production. Ensure good coverage of leaf undersides.

organic.name: Bacillus subtilis + Neem oil
organic.precautions: Apply during cooler parts of day to avoid leaf burn from neem oil.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor greenhouse humidity levels (keep below 85%)
2. Inspect leaf undersides for olive-green fuzzy growth
3. Increase ventilation and air circulation
4. Remove infected leaves promptly
5. Apply fungicides targeting leaf undersides
6. Space plants adequately for air movement

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.name: Septoria Leaf Spot
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.description: A fungal disease caused by Septoria lycopersici that creates small, circular spots with gray centers and dark borders on leaves. Black specks (pycnidia) are visible in spot centers.

chemical.name: Mancozeb + Copper hydroxide
chemical.precautions: Begin applications early in season. Focus on lower leaves where disease starts.

organic.name: Copper octanoate + Bacillus amyloliquefaciens
organic.precautions: Rotate copper and biological treatments. Apply during dry weather for best results.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout lower leaves for small circular spots with gray centers
2. Remove infected leaves and dispose in trash
3. Apply mulch around plants to prevent soil splash
4. Begin fungicide program when first spots appear
5. Water at soil level to keep foliage dry
6. Maintain good air circulation around plants

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider_m.name: Two-spotted Spider Mite
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider_m.description: Tiny arthropod pests that feed on leaf undersides, causing stippling, yellowing, and eventual leaf bronzing. Fine webbing may be visible on heavily infested plants.
treatment: Use predatory mites for biological control
Apply miticides when populations are high

chemical.name: Abamectin + Spiromesifen
chemical.precautions: Rotate miticide modes of action. Target early infestations for best control.

organic.name: Predatory mites + Neem oil
organic.usage: Release predatory mites, supplement with neem oil
organic.precautions: Avoid insecticides that harm beneficial mites. Maintain humidity above 50%.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Monitor leaf undersides with hand lens for tiny moving dots
2. Look for stippling and yellowing of leaves
3. Check for fine webbing on severely infested plants
4. Increase humidity around plants if possible
5. Apply miticides targeting leaf undersides
6. Release predatory mites for long-term control

Tomato_Target_Spot.name: Target Spot
Tomato_Target_Spot.description: A fungal disease caused by Corynespora cassiicola that creates brown spots with concentric rings on leaves, similar to early blight but typically smaller and more numerous.

chemical.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole
chemical.usage: Foliar spray covering all plant surfaces
chemical.precautions: Alternate with different fungicide groups to prevent resistance development.

organic.name: Copper hydroxide + Potassium bicarbonate
organic.precautions: Apply copper products during dry weather to avoid phytotoxicity.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Scout for small brown spots with target-like rings
2. Begin fungicide program at first symptom appearance
3. Remove infected leaves and plant debris
4. Ensure adequate plant spacing for air circulation
5. Avoid wetting foliage during irrigation
6. Rotate crops to reduce inoculum buildup

Tomato_Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.name: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV)
Tomato_Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: A viral disease transmitted by whiteflies that causes upward curling of leaves, yellowing, stunting, and reduced fruit production. No direct cure exists.
treatment: Install reflective mulches to deter whiteflies

chemical.name: Imidacloprid + Spiromesifen
chemical.usage: Systemic and contact treatment for whiteflies
chemical.application_frequency: Every 14 days during high whitefly pressure
chemical.precautions: Focus on vector control, not virus treatment. Use resistant varieties as primary strategy.

organic.name: Reflective mulch + Beneficial insects
organic.usage: Install reflective mulch, release beneficial insects
organic.precautions: Combine multiple approaches for effective whitefly management.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Plant TYLCV-resistant varieties when available
2. Install reflective mulch before planting
3. Monitor for whitefly adults using yellow sticky traps
4. Remove infected plants immediately
5. Control weeds that harbor whiteflies
6. Use row covers during plant establishment

Tomato_Tomato_mosaic_virus.name: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV)
Tomato_Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: A viral disease causing mottled light and dark green patterns on leaves, leaf distortion, and reduced fruit quality. Highly contagious through plant contact and contaminated tools.

chemical.name: No direct chemical control - focus on prevention
chemical.precautions: No cure exists. Focus entirely on prevention and sanitation.

organic.name: Prevention through sanitation + Resistant varieties
organic.precautions: Same as chemical - no treatment exists, only prevention.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Purchase certified virus-free seeds and transplants
2. Sanitize tools with 10% bleach solution between plants
3. Avoid handling plants when wet
4. Remove plants showing mosaic symptoms immediately
5. Wash hands thoroughly after handling infected plants
6. Control aphids and other potential vectors

Tomato_healthy.name: Healthy Tomato
Tomato_healthy.description: A healthy tomato plant exhibits vibrant green foliage, strong stems, regular growth patterns, and absence of disease symptoms or pest damage.
treatment: Ensure proper spacing for air circulation
Monitor regularly for early problem detection

chemical.name: Balanced fertilizer + Preventive spray program
chemical.precautions: Maintain plant health to prevent disease susceptibility.

organic.name: Compost + Beneficial microorganisms
organic.precautions: Build soil health for natural disease resistance.

step_by_step_guide: 1. Conduct soil test before planting
2. Plant in well-draining, fertile soil
3. Provide consistent water (1-2 inches per week)
4. Mulch around plants to conserve moisture
5. Monitor weekly for any signs of problems
6. Harvest regularly to maintain plant productivity
